children.value:
Linear regression is a fundamental technique in data science used to model the relationship between a dependent variable and one or more independent variables.
It is widely used for predictive analysis, trend forecasting, and determining the strength of predictors.
By fitting a linear equation to observed data, linear regression helps in understanding how the dependent variable changes with variations in the independent variables, making it a powerful tool for both explanatory and predictive modeling.

Introduction with a simple tow points line equation

children.value: Let’s annalyse how to determine the simple equation of a linear function (

children.html: y=ax+by=ax+by=ax+b

children.value: ) kowing tow points of the line.

# the known points

x = np.array([0.5, 3])
x, y

children.value: coefficents, we have to solve the following system:

children.html: y0=ax0+by_0=ax_0+by0​=ax0​+b
y1=ax1+by_1=ax_1+by1​=ax1​+b

children.value: Lets reorgenized a bit this system:

children.html: b+ax0=y0b + ax_0 = y_0b+ax0​=y0​
b+ax1=y1b + ax_1 = y_1b+ax1​=y1​

children.value: Its now easy to write it as a linear system:

children.html: [1x01x1].[ba]=[y0y1]\begin{bmatrix} 1 & x_0 \\ 1 & x_1 \end{bmatrix} . \begin{bmatrix} b \\ a \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} y_0 \\ y_1 \end{bmatrix}[11​x0​x1​​].[ba​]=[y0​y1​​]
aaa
bbb

children.value: coefficents can be determine by inversing the linear system:

children.html: [ba]=[1x01x1]−1.[y0y1]\begin{bmatrix} b \\ a \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & x_0 \\ 1 & x_1 \end{bmatrix}^{-1} . \begin{bmatrix} y_0 \\ y_1 \end{bmatrix}[ba​]=[11​x0​x1​​]−1.[y0​y1​​]

children.value:
# definition of the involved matrix :
X = np.array([[1, x[0]], [1, x[1]]])
print("X=", X)
Y = np.array([y[0], y[1]]).T
print("Y=", Y)

# Inversion of the systeme
coef = np.dot(np.linalg.inv(X), Y)
a = coef[1]
b = coef[0]
print(
    "a=",
    a,
)
print("b=", b)

# draw the obtained line
N = 10
xmin, xmax = 0.0, 4
xi = np.linspace(xmin, xmax, N)
yi = a * xi + b

fig = plt.figure()
plt.plot(x, y, "o")
plt.plot(xi, yi, "r")
plt.grid()

children.value: coefficients (i.e. to find the linear equation) that fit the best the given data.
We can rewrite the equations in the form of the following linear system:

children.html: [1x01x11x2][ba]=[y0y1y2]\begin{bmatrix} 1 & x_0 \\ 1 & x_1 \\ 1 & x_2 \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} b \\ a \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} y_0 \\ y_1 \\ y_2 \end{bmatrix}⎣⎡​111​x0​x1​x2​​⎦⎤​[ba​]=⎣⎡​y0​y1​y2​​⎦⎤​

children.value: The system can be express in a genral form:

children.html: Xβ=YX \beta=YXβ=Y

children.value: is not square, and therfore not inversible. The methode presented above is no more apllicable.
The trick is to multiply the system by the transposed of

children.html: XXX
XtXβ=XtYX^t X \beta= X^t YXtXβ=XtY
XtXX^t XXtX

# Construcion of the X matrix
X = np.array([np.ones(x.size), x]).T
X

# Computation of Xt X
np.dot(X.T, X)
The obtained matrix is a square matrix and it can proved that this matrix is symmetric, and therfore always inversible.

children.html: XtXβ=XtYX^t X \beta= X^t YXtXβ=XtY
β\betaβ

children.value: vector can be express by as :

children.html: β=(XtX)−1XtY\beta= \left( X^t X \right)^{-1} X^t Yβ=(XtX)−1XtY

children.value: This operator is the least square estimator.

# Construcion of the X matrix
X = np.array([np.ones(x.size), x]).T

# Construcion of the Y matrix
Y = y.T

print("X=", X)

print("Y=", Y)

# Computation of the least square estimator
beta = np.dot(np.linalg.inv(np.dot(X.T, X)), np.dot(X.T, Y))
print("beta=", beta)

print("The fitted linear function is:")
print("y=", beta[1], "x +", beta[0])

children.value:
# compute the coefficient using the least square methode
beta = np.polyfit(x, y, 1)
print("beta=", beta)

# creat the associate 1d polynomila function
fit = np.poly1d(beta)

N = 10
xmin, xmax = 0.0, 5
xi = np.linspace(xmin, xmax, N)
yi_numpy = fit(xi)

fig = plt.figure()
plt.plot(x, y, "o", label="Data")
plt.plot(xi, yi, "+r", label="Regression")
plt.plot(xi, yi_numpy, "g", label="Regression Numpy")
plt.legend()
plt.grid()

Lucky us, all methodes give the same results !
What is the effect of noise on the resulting regression ?

children.label: What is the effect of noise on the resulting regression ?

children.value:
N = 100
xmin, xmax = 0.0, 4


def get_data(N, sigma):
    x = np.linspace(xmin, xmax, N)
    y = (3.3 * x - 2) + sigma * np.random.randn(N)
    return x, y


def compute_reg(x, y):
    beta, residuals, rank, singular_values, rcond = np.polyfit(x, y, 1, full=True)
    fit = np.poly1d(beta)
    SStot = ((y - y.mean()) ** 2).sum()
    SSres = residuals[0]
    R2 = 1 - SSres / SStot
    return beta, fit([xmin, xmax]), R2


x, y = get_data(100, 0.0)
beta, fity, R2 = compute_reg(x, y)
fig = plt.figure()
(points_plot,) = plt.plot(x, y, "o", label="Data")
(line,) = plt.plot([xmin, xmax], fity, "-r", label="Regression")
plt.plot([xmin, xmax], fity, "-g", label="Non Noisy data")
plt.grid()
plt.legend()


@ipw.interact(N=(5, 100, 10), sigma=(0.0, 2.0, 0.1))
def update(N, sigma):
    x, y = get_data(N, sigma)
    beta, fity, R2 = compute_reg(x, y)
    points_plot.set_xdata(x)
    points_plot.set_ydata(y)
    line.set_ydata(fity)
    plt.title("$R^2$={:0.2f}".format(R2))
